posts.com:
I just had a match where it was down to my 1 HP (Focus Sash) Polteageist, Choice Specs Gholdengo under Tailwind and a Murkrow in the back. The opponent had Armarouge and Scizor.
Their Armarouge was on low HP from Polteageist's not very effective 140 BP Stored Power.

Gholdengo might be able to deal a lot of Damage to Scizor but I wasn't confident. if it lives I just die and I was afraid of it carrying Bullet Punch or something. The time for move selection was running out and I panicked, I clicked Stored Power on Scizor and I didn't select Gholdengo's move in time.

So the game made Gholdengo use Trick on Armarouge, giving Choice Specs to it which is probably the worst possible move to use at that moment. not very effective Stored Power brought Scizor to low HP and it killed Gholdengo right after. I thought I got very close to winning, I could have won if I selected literally any other move for Gholdengo but it all fell apart, something like that.

but then the Armarouge was the one to finish Polteageist off and Cursed Body activated. I only had Murkrow left and my Murkrow has Heat Wave for.. reasons. She killed Scizor but had no way of damaging Armarouge. Armarouge died from Struggle's recoil.

Actually the worst, most undeserved win of my life. By pure luck, it was a whole fucking perfect combo I didn't mean to perform. I'm not very good at Online battles but silly things like this happen sometimes and Gholdengo keeps me going.

I'm not sure if they're still here but an anon in one of these threads inspired me to run Fairy Tera blast on Polteageist for coverage. I got new weakness but I no longer get completely assraped by all the dragons running around

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52869198
I also draw so I'm not against the idea of redesigning a Pokemon. I find it interesting even if there are very few redesigns that I prefer.

Putting aside my concerning liking for Gholdengo, I can see it being one of the most divisive designs this gen (or every gen) it's not just goofy, it's absurdly goofy. While I completely understand why people hate it and won't convince anyone that Gholdengo is a good design, I can tell you why I don't like any of the redesigns I've seen either.

Gholdengo isn't a perfect design but it's complete and simple enough that any redesigns just end up throwing the whole thing out which yeah, people who hate Gholdengo would like that. all of them lean so heavily into oooh spooky chest mimic, spooky coin monster direction. They're missing Gholdengo's personality and when you remove that, it's not Gholdengo anymore.
with something like the starters you can draw a spooky fire crocodile, a magician cat, a dancer peacock in a different way and they'll still be recognizable as redesigns because it retains most of their core themes. Gholdengo designs just cut the concept of Gholdengo in half.

Gimmighoul itself is already full of personality when you look at the roaming form guys up close. I think people are too fixated on it becoming a mimic monster when it literally has a whole another form outside of the treasure chest

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52869397
What I find annoying about the chest mimic thing is that people seem to not realize that mimics are their own type of shapeshifting monsters and not possessed inanimate objects. They're a favorite fictional species of mine, but when I saw Gimmighoul I thought "Technically, it's not a mimic" so I didn't 100% expect they'd lean into that with the evolution.. the golden golem route they took makes a lot more sense to me. The world of Pokemon also has their own forms of mimics with Voltorb and Foongus anyways.

Gholdengo's surfer motif still baffles me, but it's so fun I find it hard to understand how so many people don't find it endearing.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52865883
Landorus and Gholdengo really don't have anything in common besides being used a lot.
As >>52865914 said, Lando generally prioritizes removing hazards and maybe setting them up, while Ghold doesn't set or remove hazards, but simply keeps them up.
Lando is a gluemon that's easy to slap onto any team because it can compress so many roles into a single team slot. For any singular role, there are better options, but Lando sets itself apart by taking on the most roles.
Ghold is defined by its single role of spinblocker, which it does so amazingly well that it warped the meta. It can do other things, like hit hard and be decently bulky, but that's just the cherry on top.

I would also argue that neither of them are broken. Really good, yes, but not overwhelming. Neither of them are gonna sweep your team or wall your team.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52861863
>cashgrab
If we’re nitpicking this, we’d have to say the same for pretty much all of the games. There’s no reason for 2 + 1 versions, and there never really has been. Trading was a neat idea, but it was flawed from the start. Regardless, no one should actually be buying these games anymore.

>can’t evolve Pikachu
Not really an issue in my opinion. Using it presents a small challenge, and it is neat to roleplay as Ash/Red. Sucks for the Raichu fans. I guess the game is buggy enough you could probably force it to give you one if you really wanted.

>sprites
That’s fair. I’ve never been too fond of Gen 1’s sprites, overall, so this is another that I wouldn’t really notice. GSC vastly improved the sprites in my opinion; hasn’t been topped.

>starters break the game
You aren’t forced to use them, you know. I like having the option, but I don’t think I’ve used all three outside of one playthrough (out of around 5-10).

>sterilization
That I actually agree with. It’s an issue with the series as a whole. You wouldn’t know looking at modern games (or even much older) that the original vision for pokemon was considerably more edgy (and not in the goofy comic book tier way you see with some of the villain teams).

>>52866947
>Crystal almost exclusively took the sprites from Gold because it was completed before Silver and they started the development of Crystal at the same time as when they created the sprites for Silver.
Most Silver sprites look like they're in the middle of an animation, as you sort of touched upon. It was generally easier for sprite creators to build on top of the Gold sprites. In the cases where the Silver sprite had the less dynamic counterpart, like with Arcanine, they based the animation on that sprite instead. It's easier to take a neutral-posed sprite to use as the starting and ending pose and then create what happens in the middle.

>>52855126


>>52851910
Sandile is one of those ones that you just pump full of Defence EVs.
I've noticed that pumping up a big weakness with EVs in an in-game runs tends to end better than maxing out already good stats. Even something Like Sharpedo needs max Attack but only some Speed investment and the rest can go into a Defence or Sp.Defence.

In general if you look at a pokemon stats, investment taking a Defence from really low to decent gives a bigger benefit than taking a decent defence to great.
100 ATK vs. 50, 75, 100, 125, 150 Defence gives damage multipliers of 2.0, 1.33, 1.0, 0.8, 0.67. You can see how there's diminishing returns and the biggest difference in damage dealt is from 50 to 75 Defence. That difference in an in-game setting is far more useful than 100 to 125. That being said a defensive pivot is great to have since 75 and 200 Defence still have a gap of 0.83.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52858691
Yeah. You can always just do some calculations and see how much you can EV before reaching a level cap or level you want to end at.
Just think of the earliest area you can find those EVs, in RSEORAS you can get Attack EVs from Level 2-3 Poochyena at route 1.
>TotalEVs=EXPlimit/AverageEXPperKill
Then you add them in PkHex, or use Vitamins to the nearest 10 up to 100, you hack into the PC storage or bag.
I personally have no qualms about that, it's functionally the same as grinding since there's no danger of getting killed anyway.
I don't add money, TMs, tokens etc. since those are a finite resources, or uncertain in the case of non-savescummed tokens, but stuff like multiplying berries once I've found them or the EV training trick are fair game since it's just cutting out tedium that I could do on hardware.

tl;dr: Anything that is available, safe, and possible to do in-game is fine to hack in.

>>52861213
Ryme's fight being a double battle was fun.
>Vs Ryme
>Banette and Mimikyu
I send out Greensleeves(Covert Cloak) and Douce Dame(Chesto Berry).
>Turn 1
Douce Dame breaks Mimikyu's Disguise with Ice Shard, and Greensleeves Terastalizes and Flower Tricks it into oblivion. Banette hits both my mons with Icy Wind, dropping Douce Dame's speed.
The Audience cheers for my squad, raising all their stats(because I got the first KO with a Terastal, I think).
>Houndstone sent in
>Turn 2
Banette fails a Sucker Punch aimed at Douce Dame. Greensleeves oneshots it with Flower Trick. Douce Dame sets up a Snowscape. Houndstone disappears with Phantom Force.
Audience buffs me again thanks to another KO.
>Toxtricity in
>Turn 3
My mons team up on Toxtricity, taking it out with Ice Shard into Flower Trick. Houndstone's Phantom Force hits Douce Dame, who laughs it off.
>Turn 4
Another team combo Ice Shard and Flower Trick finishes the battle.

>>52868925
>and of course, a lot of people already have a FUCKton of the pre gen 9 mon combos in their home, so why re-collect?
thing is nobody is really trading gen 9 stuff either, there are maybe 2 people here that have over 20 gen 9 aprimons on their trade list. swsh had a smaller player base yet it and sm had the liveliest trade scenes on /wfg/.
something else i've noticed is that the rate of getting aprimons in surprise trade is way lower in sv than previous games. previous games had notably popular breedjects that get wonder/surprise traded frequently like moon/love mimikyu, beast ball beldum, eevee in every apriball, moon dreepy, heavy rookidee, etc. but this gen doesn't have any mons like that, besides maybe charmander and scorbunny. i've surprise traded a dozen boxes worth of breedjects and have gotten less than 10 unique aprimons, and almost none of them were from gen 9.
the lack of enthusiasm for breeding/trading this gen feels like it's shared with the entire fanbase rather than being a /wfg/ problem. i wonder why, breeding is technically easier now so you'd expect to see more breedjects, but in reality it's the opposite.

>decent options for trick room?
You try to fit one solution based around the expected trick room abusers and hope it works or build a team that can stop/outlive the setup.

>How to use protect?
Eating time off weather/trick/screens is good but it's also something you learn to use to gain leverage against the enemy team. Watch old worlds matches and see how they use protect. That's the best advice I can give you since it's a personal choice to run it and use it defensively since most people don't bother with Choice items too often in Doubles outside of boosting Rock Slides etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52866456
Meowscarada and Oranguru seem like reasonably popular anti-trick room pokemon. Meowscarada more incidentally, because it's a good pokemon otherwise and just so happens to learn trick room, but the fact that it commonly runs focus sash to enable overgrow makes it easier to reverse it. Oranguru has versatility against trick room. It can reverse it traditionally, instruct your opponent's trick room setter to reverse it as soon as they set it, or use imprison to prevent it from going up at all, and if you end up forced to live with trick room for some reason, it can use its low speed to function and enable your other pokemon (except Gholdengo)

>>52869195
For one, more minmaxed stat distribution. A mon with 80 across the board isn't going to be as threatening as an 80/120/60/40/60/120 mon even though they have the same BST. New mons have also pretty much always been getting an exclusive or nigh-exclusive move or ability since Gen 6, many of which are good. Stuff like Purifying Salt or Good as Gold or Flower Trick or Commander are absolutely nutso, and there's more mons possessing crazy bullshit on that level than in previous gens.
Also in SV they did introduce like a dozen mons with 570 BST or more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52869195
For one example, let's take the latest gimmick, Terastalization. A pokemon can change into any one type, and gain an additional STAB bonus from that type. But if a pokemon were to terastalize into a type it already has, its STAB boost is upped to 2x, instead of the usual 1.5x. It doesn't sound like much, but it's allowed things like Golduck to be viable a couple of tiers higher than it would normally be, because tera water in the rain (another 1.5x boost) can push out a ridiculous amount of damage, all without changing BSTs.

Another example is Chi-Yu. Its ability lowers other pokemon's special defense, while it itself has an optimized 135 special attack. (it has a BST of 570) In the sun (1.5x damage for fire type attacks) a Chi-Yu that has terastalized into fire type can actually overpower a Blissey.

posts.name: Anonymous

I don't understand farm hands
say that one has a work speed of 20min, does that mean that for it to farm and harvest automatically I have to give it a berry that grows and matures within 20mins without withering?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52869266
Basically work speed is that the Farm Hand tries to do the actions it's allowed to do (Harvest/Plant a berry) whenever that time is up.
So in the case of 20 minutes, it only tries to do things once every 20 minutes.
Every time this happens, it can do as many actions as their efficiency allows.
Also, every time the work speed timer is up, they'll either expend one energy to do all those actions, or if they're out of energy, they instead gain one energy by resting.
So once they run out of energy, you basically have to account for the fact that every other action will be wasted.

>>52869543
Most wallbreakers can't do that, And the ones that do will inevitably get banned. See Kyurem styling on Finch as an example. Dugtrio actually enables skillful play. It's one of the few ways to genuinely punish switching. Which otherwise is almost impossible to punish. Arena trap has so many options to counter it that it's not even funny, All of Shed shell, Pivot moves. Levitate/Flying types, Ghost types all have the ability to completely stuff a trapping attempt. The fact that duggy is very hard to safely get on the field to begin with due to a combination of hazards, It being incredibly frail and the fact that numerous pokemon can eat a hit from duggy because it's not that strong, 100 atk stab EQ might seem powerful but neutral targets would need to be chipped, Some pokemon that are weak to Dug can even take the hit and retaliate and kill it. Even Air balloon can be used to avoid Dug's EQ and force the other player to actually hit the pokemon that's currently in before switching in duggy for the kill. It's much harder to use dugtrio than people make it seem.

The first fanfic I ever read when I was 12 was an Altoshipping fic called "Guardian of the Chosen One" by XD-385. It gets a bit insane with a dark shonen plot where Ash basically discovers he has Goku-esque superpowers (because he's the "Chosen One" mentioned in the Orange Islands), but it's a guilty pleasure that I still enjoy. There's only a couple nsfw chapters sprinkled throughout a much larger story; it takes place during Ash's Hoenn journey, and Ash finds himself missing Latias so much that he decides to go back and visit her in Alto Mare. He and Latias reconnect, have sex, have two shiny Lati babies, and eventually get married. And I LOVED all of it. I should really re-read it again sometime.

Their spouse wanted a child, Arven, but lost the ability to love their family and leave for their twist. I think we'll meet them in the 2nd DLC wave.

To further boost the tinfoil hat contingent in this thread, there is a strong four element to Geeta’s design: four buttons on the coat, on her sleeves, four buckles, notable squares over her eyes, and so on. The other big four motif in this game concerns terastalization (where the name is both a pun on “terra” the Latinate root for Earth/ground, and tera, Latin prefix for four) and thus Area Zero, where a prominent weird four element symbol is left completely unexplained.

Which is interesting because Area Zero’s other motif is also numerological in nature: it’s the number six, prominently associated with the “Time Machine” and the professor AI whose functioning is explicitly referred to as depending on the hexagonal constructs of Terastal crystals. It’s also the symbol most associated with the mysterious disk Pokémon referred to in the Violet/Scarlet book

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
On the one hand, I definitely agree with the criticism of Geeta—her team is poorly constructed and misused, her model is kind of off, etc.

But on the other hand, I really appreciate that more than any other champion, it’s clearly demonstrated that Geeta has a Job with Responsibilities. And not just exciting “fight criminals/investigate strange happenings” responsibilities, either. She’s responsible for managing the elite four and gym leaders, the fact that she’s the one bringing Penny on shows she’s managing general personnel decisions and the LP system (which in itself is a program for dealing with potentially dangerous Tera Pokémon, hence you getting an LP bonus for finding them). She’s actually putting in the managerial work to make the League run (yes, in terms of power she’s like a CEO, but her actual job is so much more hands-on than that).

She’s not going to be the villain of the DLC—that is blatantly going to be your history teacher—but I do think we’ll get more out of her in DLC. My big hope is that there’s a rematch that’s basically “yes, I know I said I never hold back, but the fact is I do have to handicap myself because a perfect record means I am not doing my job correctly. This time it’s cards on the table, champion vs. champion, show me what you’ve got”, and now what was formerly her ace is now just her setup lead.

Because Gallade's niche in OU is being able to bust up stall with its incredibly powerful stabs.

Agility is better in UU where things are not as strong/bulky so he can get away with ditching SD in favor of a coverage move and can use it's alright special bulk to agility up with the aid of a defensive tera or a passive mon in front of it, while not losing out on kills because gallade already hits hard af.

Double Dance is cute but Gallade's third coverage move is pretty much essential as it allows it to choose what checks it and what doesn't (leaf blade is very common since it's 135 BP and it kills slowbro/king, whom can wall its stabs, while being neutral on things like hatterene and other psychics).

>>52868282
You don't need to go anywhere or even really play much of Pokemon GO to get Meltan, it's actually pretty easy to get it and trade it to the main games:

>connect your Pokemon GO to your Home account in the Go settings
>send any random Pokemon into Home (don't forget to pick it up before sending a Meltan)
>this will give you a "mysterious box"
>open it
>Meltan will spawn around you for half an hour
>catch one, go back to the settings menu and send it into Home
>enjoy your Meltan

If you want to get a Melmetal as well, then catch as many Meltan as you can because you get candy for catching them and you need Meltan candy to evolve it (also use Pinap berries because that makes them drop more candy). This will take a bit of time but you can reopen the box every 3 days to make more Meltan appear, then once you have 400 candy you can evolve it before sending it to Home.

If you want a shiny one you'll have to wait because they only enable the chance for a shiny one to appear during certain events, such as the anniversary (which is in July). The shiny rate is something like 1/64 and they let you open the box more often during that time, so it's a fairly easy hunt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mini arc where Ash is supposed to be training for the Indigo Conference:
>Two 'prologue' episodes of sorts. The first is "It's Mr. Mime Time", in which Delia gets Mr Mime and its also the first night in which Ash, Misty, and Brock stay at the Ketchum residence. And the next day in "Showdown at the Po-ké Corral", Professor Oak explains there is two months until the indigo league conference so Ash should train. (For the sake of simplicity, an average month is about 30 days, so Ash now has 60 days ahead of him to train. Which is a total of 62 days when also factoring the two 'prologue' episodes that setup the routine.)
>During the two month training period Ash, Misty, and Brock live at the Ketchum residence for 48 more days (48/62)
>Ash sleeps on the floor on a futon in his own room as seen in both "Showdown at the Po-ké Corral" and "Make Room for Gloom".
>Misty sleeps in Ash's room on his actual bed as seen in "Make Room for Gloom".
>Brock is never shown for where he sleeps, could be the couch, could be Delia's bed.
>Ash is never shown to protest to Misty sleeping in his bed, nor is it ever shown that he was told by Delia to let Misty sleep in his bed.
>Brock is shown as early riser regularly when making Breakfast for the rest of the household, Ash is shown to be the one who sleeps in, Misty gets up earlier than Ash.
>The trio and Delia spend 3 days and 3 nights at a beach resort. 2 of those 3 days are covered in "The Evolution Solution" and "The Pi-Kahuna". (3/62)
>1 night is shown of the trio camping outside during "Lights, Camera, Quack-tion". (1/62)
>The Narrator states Ash only has 3 weeks left in "To Master the Onixpected".
>1 night is shown of the trio spent sleeping in an RV during "The Ancient Puzzle of Pokémopolis". (1/62)
>The trio officially leave the Ketchum residence at the beginning of the last week during "Bad to the Bone" to go to the Indigo Plateau. (7/62)
TL;DR: Misty got to sleep in Ash's bed at his house for 50 days.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52863973
It's clear the other characters view Nemona as socially odd and her reactions to paradox mons as atypical. I do think the writers were framing her as a typical "shonen" protagonist obsessed with her goal, but when in the more grounded context of other characters, Nemona's strengths and weaknesses intentionally look more like autism traits. Despite that, she's not presented as lesser, and people engage with her based on her strengths.

It's clever writing and I wonder if they'll ever acknowledge it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52869363
I definitely think Nemona was meant to come off as odd on purpose. Don't think they'll ever flat out say she's autistic or mentally ill or whatever, but I'm pretty sure they meant to portray her as such.
All the comments in Area Zero about how strange she is, including Penny telling her to see a doctor because her reactions to things aren't normal. The post-game thing where she had to be told to her face that people don't wanna battle her because she couldn't take a hint, along with the comment of an invisible wall between her and others. Her stalkerish, obsessive behaviour with the MC that I feel goes far beyond just a regular girl wanting a friend, such as saying that the MC should only battle her, or waiting ahead at gyms for the MC (they kind of highlighted how that behaviour was odd by flat out having Nemona comment on how "it's totally just a coincidence and she totally wasn't just hanging around waiting for you"). Her inability to take no for an answer. If it were just her obsession with battling, I could believe they just meant for her to be a generic shounen protag type character. But all these other little details have me convinced that she's genuinely supposed to have a few screws loose.

I'm curious how many people think about the OP posts as writing prompts. Plenty of the titles, either of the image or the thread, actually point in the general direction of a less-than-obvious interpretation of the picture.

Like how this one is pointing out how Torii gates are meant to represent "crossing" from the mundane to the sacred, often with implied purification. This being from a Japanese Pixiv account, it's almost certainly more than just a literal portal, hence using "Grudges Settled" to denote interpreting it as passing on, either in the "finally gets to die" sense or just calming the fuck down.

>>52865523
Hanke's suckered me into doing GBL full-time. I've gotten over 700k stardust so far this season (1.5m last season doing only Master League and the GO Battle Days, aka the first season I actually tried) and I've used the rank 19 ECTM to give my perfect lvl. 41 Reshiram Fusion Flare. While I feel significantly more mental pain every day, including a new variant of stress headaches that hurt a lot worse, it'll still be worth it once I'll no longer have to invite other people to any mega raids that'll ever come up in the future.

If you can put up with it, I'd recommend at the very least throwing in whatever you want and doing at least whatever amount of battles you need to do during GO Battle Days specifically. You'll get a ton of stardust just by getting at least one win per set, and the timed research that gives you an Elite Charge TM usually doesn't care if you win or loss, so it basically only costs your sanity. I've paid in my sanity, and I'd say it was mostly worth shaving three years off my life from stress.

To fix the design, i removed everything humanoid while intentionally leaving all other design elements (sausage toes, pompadour, patterns) identical:

- Bend the knees backwards like a bird, instead of forwards like a human
- Change its human arms and hands into bird wings
- Change its skinny human torso into a long bird neck

Your humanoid abomination of a gay duck is now a fabulous peacock/ostrich monster that will not hesitate to kick your shit in with his dance moves and then push your shit in with his corkscrew cock, he’s still gay for making fun of his hair.

>DLC Pack 1
The director calls everyone in for another semester. Another time lapse cutscene like the beginning of the game plays, and you're let out for summer break. You now have access to custom clothing outfits, but they're still pre-matched tops and bottoms. You unlock more classes with other characters like Rika.
Nemona's parents come in for the break and we meet them. They talk about how they want to improve the Rotom Phone and give you some gimmick new feature to find hidden abilities in the wild. This is the told to go test it in the newly unlocked area just south of Paldea, real world Morocco. There, you're set to investigate the new mysterious Pokemon that's appeared, and you find the Past Paradox Beast fusion/Future Paradox Sword fusion after completing the main story. Jacq asks what's going on and tells the player it resembles the other paradoxes. He fills you in that he worked with the professor and Clavell on the Pokedex app of Paldea and had some idea of their existence, but now Clavell, Jacq, and your friends don't know what to make of another Paradox being this far away from Area Zero, with Arven questioning how it resembles the one that was in the Scarlet/Violet Book. Jacq and Nemona's parents are happy though the new feature works, and then you're free to go do some other stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52868700
i bought monster sanctuary and i really like it. id recommend it. the game even gives you shifted monsters to hunt for so monsters have 3 colors. theyre not like shinies so theyre not super rare or anything. they have skill trees you can unlock. theres boss monsters and you need 5 stars (how you perform) to get their eggs. i really enjoy the world. it was very fun and relaxing for me to explore it/solve the puzzles. combat does not just rely on super effective moves so the game actually made it worth it for me to use support monsters that build up shields and do burns/poison. evolution does not improve a monster overall. it just turns it into a different role from what i understand. my supporter would evolve into a damage dealer. the monster designs look okay. nothing special but not ugly. instead of always coming up with random creatures they will put stuff like goblins and yetis into the game. the animations are nicely done. you can easily add new team members without grind because the eggs you hatch are close in level to your team. you dont have to put puzzle solving monsters in your team.

what i dont like is that the game has following monsters and you can use every monster you have for that (not just your team) BUT i usually end up having a flying monster or something else i need for a puzzle as my follower making it pretty pointless to me. you also dont build a bond with them through talking even though the game shows your first monster talking. i hated the quest of having to find fur cause it took way too long. i didnt put every monster i liked into my team cause it wasnt the right role but idk i just like balanced/harmonious teams.

you will have a team of 6 members but only 3 of them fight. all of them will gain exp. the game will let you play without stopping you every 3 secs with cutscenes but does not have much story.

id definitely recommend getting it for the steam sale price right now.

coromons look pretty hideous so i havent played it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52860105
Just off the top of my head, these are some things they should change about this Pokemon

>Boost the attack a little bit
>More HP
>Give it Smack Down, Stealth Rock, Taunt, Torment, Wide Guard, Endeavor, Work Up, Stomping Tantrum, Breaking Swipe, Metal Burst, Punishment, Retaliate, Revenge, Beat Up, Payback

All these are based on its lore or the fact that it has a big hammer. I tried to avoid moves that sound cool on it but don't make a ton of sense, like EQ or Wood Hammer. Instead I went with moves that will increase its utility. I think stealth rock and taunt alone would be a big get, but a lot of those other moves have pretty neat implications. Smack down just seems obvious for flavor but I also like the idea of it using metal burst, payback or revenge in tandem with its slow speed to try and catch people. And did you know that it learns ice hammer, pounce and skitter snack? That's kind of strange, but it's clear to me that they had a mindset of this being a Pokémon that's trying to deal damage with high BP moves while also debuffing opponents at the same time with weaker damaging moves. That way you can put an assault vest on it and give it a lot of staying power so it can be disruptive but also bulky

>>52860105
I think the problem is that people judge it based on what they think it should be rather than what it actually is.
GF isn't innocent in this, with the dex entry describing how it bullies a notably obnoxious stallmon. That leads people to think it should be a stallbreaker and laugh at it for failing to do so.
But Vikavolt already taught us that whoever writes dex entries and whoever comes up with the stats aren't on speaking terms.
Tinkaton is a supportmon. Strong support movepool, workable bulk, Mold Breaker letting it use status moves on Gholdengo, and Gigaton Hammer to prevent it from being passive.
Saying it's bad because >75 is like saying Grimmsnarl is bad because it's a slow frail mixed attacker.

Although I do agree that its stat spread is impressively bad relative to its BST. I just disagree that it's shit overall, since everything else makes up for it.

That IS what happened, except the child the original Mew gave birth to was its own clone - it's implied they used the Somatic Nuclear Transfer method of cloning (which was the only viable method known in real life at the time the game released, most famously used in the Dolly the Sheep experiment) - and they modified the clone baby after the fact. You can surmise that he went after Fuji to learn the truth about the rumors he may have heard of a mysterious super-Pokemon, then went for the Master Ball when Fuji confirmed Mewtwo was, in fact, real, but there's nothing concrete that says TR was involved in Mewtwo's creation.

posts.com:
Try to put aside how you feel about the new games for a moment.
And about the series in general and the generations thereof.
And about the developers.
Now, answer this.
Is this the biggest soft reboot the series has seen?
It’s easy to assume that Gen 5 was THE massive soft reboot because Black and White had zero old Pokémon until postgame, but something about SV makes it seem like it can beat that even with old Pokemon by virtue of everything else.
The gameplay is different. Fully open world, all Pokemon are visible to the player before encounter and there is no tall grass. Trainer battles are effectively completely optional. Local and online multiplayer is supported. ACTUAL multiplayer. Multiple people playing the game at the same time. Significantly larger in scale than Let’s Go’s multiplayer. Gyms, and everything else, can be tackled in any order, though the levels are still set and not scaled.
The story is different. You have three routes to progress through, all culminating in a finale. Beating the Champion, or Top Champion in this case, is not even close to the end of the game. The legendary isn’t presented as a threat, but a partner…until it technically IS the threat, presenting this as a twist.
The music is different. Five sections of the map all have the same music throughout, with towns having remixed versions of that theme, and variations playing during Pokémon battles. The music is also different depending on whether or not you’re riding the legendary.
How will the brand change from this dramatic shift in what “makes” a traditional Pokémon game?

>stars a Mawile and Zoura who work as street performers with the mawile acting and the Zoura making illusions to fill in the roles
>their special talent is being able to bullshit and lie through situations because they aren't the strongest fighters
>in this world, "mystery dungeons" only just begin cropping up recently, are remarkable because they have limitless food and money
>plot begins in earnest when a mystery dungeon appears suddenly, transforming a guy's storefront into a dungeon
>maw and zoura check it out to make sure its not too dangerous, when its shown to be a low lv dungeon, shopkeeper decides to turn it into an attraction people can visit if they pay him
>in this world there's a lot of seedy political stuff going on with gangs that want to control the new resources that the maw and zo only escape because they can lie/illusion their way out of getting jumped by bands of goons
>also there's UBs running around?
>plot picks up and the MCs are warped into some alt dimension
>in the company of a bunch of UBs
>it's revealed the mystery dungeons are being remotely built by a Stakataka as "bunkers" with limitless resources for the good of the pkmn inhabitants
>the reason why is because humans discovered how to dimension hop and took over the world the UBs are from, now the UBs are fighting back the humans and making dungeons as a failsafe since the MC's world is next on their list
>eventually its MCs versus human trainers but MCs are clearly outmatched
>humans arrive in the MCs world
>but..it's just a barren waste, and anyone who sets foot there is seized by some noxious gas
>humans fuck off because this world isn't worth
>IT WAS ZOROARK
>happy end, Stakataka keeps making dungeons because they're cool, guilds and stuff start popping up

That is not how it works.
Consoles can be backwards compatible and play the previous gen's games, but a game that runs on the PS1 and PS2 is de facto a PS1 game.

>>52868464
Any 5-star will drop one specific kind at a 10.8% rate, depending on the Pokémon
5-star Gengar, Blissey, Glalie, Drifblim, Amoonguss, Eelektross, Palafin, Cetitan and Dondozo all have a chance at dropping any of the 5 flavors (replacing the usual 4 mint drops), which means you're 5x as likely to get an herb drop from them
6-star raids increase the rate to >13% and they have their own set of Pokémon that drop all of the herbs (some are on both lists like Blissey but not all of them) but obviously they're significantly more difficult and slow to do than 5-stars

Since pokemon invoked the existence of a multiverse a couple generations back, you can say that G/S/C takes place in a different universe/timeline from HG/SS. Or you could just decide that G/S/C is 100% noncanon and is fully replaced by the similar-but-slightly-different HG/SS content. Either way the idea of steel types being " recently discovered" doesn't work if you allow for the type chart to be something that exists within canon rather than a game extraction, because then the nature of reality somehow changes as pokemon researchers discover things. The setting turns into madness where subjective reality trumps scientific rigor and it gets worse then harder you try to make it make sense. Best to just ignore the retcon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52820975
As a video game, as good a time as any. Masters is a VERY static game in its skeleton crew phase that you'll see experience almost in full in about two months. The major storylines can be played and replayed at any time, the difficulty of the reoccurring battles is never adjusted, and the last new permanent battle challenge was the Moltres boss fight over a year ago. >>52821235 is right in that so long as you get a couple of the newest power-crept toys you'll quickly have a huge leg up in winning the battles, then that much more once you get a couple more, and so on. BUT since the most important game modes are almost never updated you can spin for who you want and make the reoccurring challenges as easy or difficult as you want (more restrictions to the Elite 4 fights, how many rounds you want to squeeze out of the legendary gauntlet, etc.)

For getting the characters you want, you need to throw 36,600 free gems into a banner to get an extra free pick from that banner (at which point you pick the rare character). You get nearly that much the first time you clear the Champion Stadium tutorial, and subsequently get about 30~32,000 a month if you do every little thing. So in practice you skip every 3 or so characters until you have the gems to assure 1, so spin for who you really want and you'll have no problem getting them.

>>52826603
Or this. You clear the story and then you're mostly doing sub-10 minute daily log-ins and fighting the Elite 4 once a week. Doesn't ask very much time at least.

>>52826095
DO NOT! Pull on any banners unless you have 36,600 gems ready to pity for them. The best unit currently available for a new player right now is arguably Serena and Greninja if you wanna use your new-player gems to pull for her, you should have enough by the time she leaves. It always helps to have a strong unit starting out to off-type carry you through some stages you just don’t have the optimal pairs for yet.

The way the pity system works in this game is, after you spend 36,600 gems you can pick any unit in the pool (which 99% of the time you’re gonna be picking the featured unit). If you have less than 36,600 gems, and you burn all your gems pulling and don’t get the unit before the banner goes away, you’ve wasted your gems for nothing. Be thankful when your luck is good and you get a unit in 1-2 multi pulls, but ALWAYS assume the game will fuck you over, and budget accordingly.

You can upgrade units to 6*EX using materials you get from Champion Stadium, which gives them a general power boost and a buff to their sync move dependent on their class. Generally speaking, you should prioritize your supports first, because they get a double sync buff on their first sync, which is the most generally useful perk.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52857128
Not-quite-F2P teams I used which didn’t include the featured units:

Alola
>1- Kiawe 4/5 EX
>2- Elio 2/5
>3- Hala 2/5 EX
>Rating: Hard
You really need a fully-invested EX striker for this one to bypass their endure. Elio is the MVP here for his high-damage AoE move which can whittle down the sides, even without the debuffing effects which unlock at 3/5. Hala needs to be at least 2/5 EX to get Haymaker and MGR on Ice Hammer, or else he’ll just be too slow and not deal enough damage.

Unova
>1- Skyla 5/5 EX
>2- SS Hilda 3/5 EX
>3- free space
>Rating: EZ
If you rolled for SS Hilda, this battle is over by the first sync. If not I’m sure you could make do with Ghetsis as your damage dealer.

Hoenn
>1- Phoebe 1/5
>2- Zinnia 5/5 (no mega)
>3- SS Wally
>Rating: Hard
The hardest fight for me because I just didn’t have many units to play around with. If your Zinnia is EX’d, you should be able to do Phoebe/May/Zinnia fairly easily, basically just use May to set rain for Zinnia’s multipliers. Without EX Zinnia just doesn’t do enough damage to take out all three opponents before fainting.

Scizor is broken if it gets a substantial lead. The problem is, you're likely not gonna get that from laning and as a jungler it doesn't do enough damage during a gank to be a big enough threat and rack up some snowballing. You either need to get a really good lane or gank a lane with god-tier laners (like say PikaMime) to get it going.
Likewise, if you fall behind, Scizor is worthless. It's probably the single most reliant on its numbers than any Pokemon, because there really isn't anything more to its gameplay than press button get lifesteal
